english_translation: Narrated by Dhu al-Jawshan al-Dibabi: I came to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ after (the battle of) Badr was completed with a young female horse of mine called al-Qarhaa for him to use. He said: I have no need for it, and if I wanted I could repay you with the best of the armors from Badr, and make what I would have repaid you today with something else. He said: Then I have no need for it. Then he said: O Dhu al-Jawshan, will you not embrace Islam so that you are among the first of this affair? I said: No. He said: Why? I said: Because I see your people are attached to you. He said: How did the news of their deaths reach you? I said: It has reached me. I said: If you would guide me. I said: If you overcome the Kaaba and dwell in it. He said: Perhaps if you live you will see that. He said: O Bilal, take the man's saddlebag and provide him from the Ajwa dates. When I turned back, he said: Indeed he is the best horseman of Banu Amir. He said: By Allah, I was with my family at al-Ud when a rider came. I said: From where? He said: From Makkah. I said: What did the people do? He said: By Allah, Muhammad ﷺ has overcome it and dwelt in it. I said: My mother has ruined me had I embraced Islam at that time. Then I asked him for al-Hira so he would give it to me. He said: By Allah, I will not drink oil from a cup nor will a mule be broken in my land.

chainIssues: Yunus (the father) and the grandfather both narrate using 'an, introducing ambiguity about direct transmission.
The grandfather of Isa ibn Yunus is identified only as 'Abu Ishaq al-Sabi' with unknown reliability status (majhul al-hal).

potential_issues.issue: Yunus uses 'an transmission term despite being the father of Isa
potential_issues.impact: While Yunus is graded as Saduq (reliable), the use of 'an creates ambiguity. However, this is common in family transmissions and does not severely compromise the chain given Yunus' reliability.

potential_issues.issue: The grandfather of Isa ibn Yunus has uncertain reliability (majhul al-hal)
potential_issues.impact: The grandfather's reliability has not been clearly documented by major hadith scholars. This introduces a weakness at a critical point in the chain.
Combined with his uncertain status, this further weakens the connection between the grandfather and Dhu al-Jawshan.

potential_issues.issue: Rabia bint Iyad is identified as majhul al-hal (unknown condition)
potential_issues.impact: Her reliability has not been documented by major hadith scholars, making it impossible to assess the trustworthiness of this segment of the chain.

potential_issues.issue: The hadith is transmitted through a female narrator from her grandfather
potential_issues.impact: While female narration is valid in hadith, the generational gap (granddaughter reporting from grandfather) combined with the unknown status of Rabia creates weakness in this link.

potential_issues.issue: This is a short and simple hadith about a physical action
potential_issues.impact: The brevity and nature of the hadith (an observation) suggests it could be subject to variation and misremembering across generations.
